title: Ending the use of children in street begging, hawking, and in hazardous occupations including domestic work
decision_details: - According to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, a child is defined as a person under the age of 18 years. According to the latest statistics, about 30% of the total population of the country belongs to the child population. It has been identified that some children are forced to do any kind of work for various reasons, beg in public places with either their mother or father, or become a victim of human trafficking as a "street child" and engage in begging in public places with someone other than their parents, and sell various things. Accordingly, the Cabinet, on being presented by the Minister of Women and Child Affairs the programme planned by her Ministry to strictly implement the existing legal provisions by the relevant authorities so that the use of children under the age of 16 years in begging and hawking and the employment of young children between the ages of 16-18 years in hazardous occupations including domestic work could be strictly prohibited from 2025-07-01, and to make the public aware through a comprehensive publicity programme, decided to grant its concurrence for the same.
